Unfortunately there's a lot of misinformation going around about tasers. I'm an former police officer. A taser can only be shot once, then the cartridge that houses the leads and wires has to be replaced. It's simple to do, and can be done in about 2 seconds if you have a replacement cartridge. So the question I would have to ask is "Did the taser that was taken have a replacement cartridge that is commonly held on the bottom of the taser's handle?". Not all tasers are equipped with replacement cartridges, but many are.  If so, the officer was justified in shooting Brooks. If not, then the taser no longer posed a risk to the officer. The risk to the officer is not immediate, because the taser is not a lethal weapon unless the target has a heart condition, such as A-Fib. The threat to the officer is being incapacitated, allowing the suspect to take his/her sidearm. If there was a replacement cartridge held on the taser's handle, the officer was justified in using lethal force. If there was no replacement cartridge the officer would not be justified in shooting Brooks. Unfortunately no one is asking that question. This case is being politicized when a man's life is at stake, simply because he wore a badge, and the suspect was black.
Sure, Rayshard was calm until he was criminally violent.  BLM is pushing for a "no police force under any circumstances" policy, and the sane people in the country do not agree with that.

To the Twins, the taser is a single shot weapon that uses compressed nitrogen gas to propel a pair of darts at the target. The darts are barbed and connected to the taser by fine wires. Upon deployment the taser sends electrical pulses down the wires to interrupt/interfere with voluntary muscle control. The pulses usually continue for six seconds. On some models there is a second cartridge clipped to the butt end of the pistol grip. In order to fire the taser a second time the first cartridge must be unclipped, discarded and replaced with the second cartridge. Alternatively, if the darts lodge in the targets clothing or skin, you can pull the trigger again to send another set of electrical pulses down the wires, again for six seconds.

NoNow Hiring: Police Officer

Are you interested in becoming part of the occupation with the highest suicide rate of any profession? If you choose not to kill yourself, you‚Äôll be happy to know that a 2013 study published by the National Institutes of Health found the average life expectancy of a police officer to be 57. Does a divorce rate of almost certainty sound great to you?

Well then, once you go through an invasive and detailed background check, physiological examination, physical examination, fitness test, written test and a 6 month long (often live in) boot camp style academy, you‚Äôll be released to the streets where uncertainty and possible death wait around every corner!

Before your first tour of duty, you can look forward to being issued used and often expired body armor that may or may not fit well but will still ‚Äúprobably‚Äù stop a bullet. A used firearm, sometimes 20 years old or older with no maintenance record, will be what you depend upon for your life. Rest assured that more often than not your equipment will be whatever was cheapest! You will be trained to the state MINIMUM standards, gray areas will often be entered in training as you‚Äôre given a poorly photocopied and dated handout to read on your own time for your official training. Sometimes you will go your entire career without getting a refresher on some of the courses you had in the academy!

But that‚Äôs not all!

- How would you like to work 6 days on, 2 days off

- Rotate to midnights every 2 weeks

- Weekends, holidays are a must, every year

- Mandatory overtime, often with no notice!

- Court on your days off

- Natural disaster, blizzard, pandemic ‚Äì forget your family, home and personal safety and get to work slacker.

- Morning and or afternoon court on your midnight rotation (Sleep??‚Ä¶.Suck it up butter cup!)

- An entry-level police officer starts off making $31,965 per year on average in the US according to reported salaries by Indeed users! Finally get that used car from 2003 you‚Äôve been eyeing up!

- You‚Äôll have a split second to make a choice, but don‚Äôt fear! The Monday morning quarterbacks and Facebook lawyers will have your back and be sure to correct you with how they would have handled the situation better.

- Eating at a restaurant? ‚Äì make sure to request they hold the spit, ground glass, and rat poison

- Dated equipment ‚Äì by the rust old locker full! Some of which is known to cause crippling injury - (But it looks squared away and it‚Äôs the way we‚Äôve always done it)

- Risk everything for people who hate you ‚Äì even if you‚Äôre killed ‚Äì the lawyers will come after your estate and leave your wife and kids in the gutter. - Assaulted and injured at a rate three times higher than any other profession

A taser can only shoot one set of probes per engagement. But there are contacts built into the cartridge that allows for what is called a "drive stun", where the operator can press the taser into the subject or a second subject and discharge a five second charge if dealing with multiple assailants. The taser can also be engaged with the cartridge removed in a similar manner. Most officers carry at least one extra cartridge or more.

Tennessee v. Garner, 471 U.S. 1 (1985), is a civil case in which the Supreme Court of the United States held that, under the Fourth Amendment, when a law enforcement officer is pursuing a fleeing suspect, the officer may not use deadly force to prevent escape unless "the officer has probable cause to believe that the suspect poses a significant threat of death or serious physical injury to the officer or others."

Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386 (1989), was a United States Supreme Court case where the Court determined that an objective reasonableness standard should apply to a civilian's claim that law enforcement officials used excessive force in the course of making an arrest, investigatory stop, or other "seizure" of his person.

While overcharging in a criminal case is theoretically impermissible, courts are unlikely to address claims of overcharging because the charges are often supported by probable cause. While a trial might ultimately lead to a Not Guilty verdict on a particular charge, the charge is still supported by probable cause. ¬†
Moreover, while a police officer can be sued in a civil lawsuit for wrongful arrest, prosecutors enjoy complete immunity as long as they are performing the duties of a prosecutor. ¬†

Why Is Overcharging in a Criminal Case a Problem?

While overcharging in a criminal case is common, that does not mean it‚Äôs right. Once a person is charged with an offense they need to spend money to hire a lawyer. And in many cases, people who are charged with a crime will face at least temporary incarceration.
Prosecutors are vested with a tremendous amount of power as the can singlehandedly determine a punishment by deciding what crime or crimes they wish to charge a defendant with. When coupled with mandatory minimum sentences, this means prosecutors can easily place pressure on a defendant to take a plea bargain to avoid the possibility of a longer sentence for additional or more severe crimes. ¬†
From a systemic standpoint, overcharging benefits the prosecutor, who knows that a defendant is likely to plead to a lesser offense rather than take a case to trial. As a result, more than 95% of criminal cases nation-wide result in a plea bargain.
